text: what's up outliers quick market update two things on the agenda first we have Visa with its new antitrust lawsuit coming out which we'll talk about quickly and then we're going to take a look at you meaning Unity because there's a lot of talk about some trades flowing in that are of interesting size meaning 5,000 lot options trades this actually popped up earlier for me today and I think it's kind of interesting to keep an eyeball on so let's start with Visa what's going on here well it's pretty straightforward so you can see that the justice department accuses Visa of stifling competition in the debit card business so why does this matter well it essentially shows that the justice department is starting to attack some of these perceived monopolies I don't exactly want to go as far as to call it as a monopoly but you can see that Visa controls more than 60 of debit card processing and this is one of the really interesting factors that go into a economy and overall capitalistic structure like we have here is where is that line drawn between letting good businesses grow and Thrive versus good businesses being given excess advantages that then allow them to dominate a landscape and it's a really interesting discussion to be had but we can see here it says Visa handles more than 60 of debit card transactions and collects more than 7 billion in annual processing fees and it uses

text: this could be the cat I don't instinctually see him here based on what I've seen him do previously meaning when I've seen him establish and change previous positions it's not across a bunch of different expirations across a bunch of different strikes from what I've seen he tends to layer into something and then when he wants to add more exposure he'll layer into something else but this is all with the giant caveat we're not done yet right now like I said in that series I think we're still in we're at the end or the be the end of 21 or the beginning of 2022 so we're getting there but we still have a ways to go but all I'm saying is this looks a little bit different than what I've seen so far does that mean it can't be him of course not it could be does that mean that every time we see 5,000 lot trades that it is him also absolutely not there are there's a human tendency to use round numbers you'll see things like this this is a bigger trade for sure but you'll see 5,000 blocks 2500 blocks 10,000 blocks those are just instinctual numbers that people use when you're trading at larger sizes so if you decide that you're going to put on a bigger position that's worth a few million million dollars you're kind of backed into a a trade right like a standard sizing most people are not

text: are just instinctual numbers that people use when you're trading at larger sizes so if you decide that you're going to put on a bigger position that's worth a few million million dollars you're kind of backed into a a trade right like a standard sizing most people are not coming in to put in a trade that's you know 1,526 it's going to be a round number more often than not that's why if we take a look at these strikes in unity you'll notice the same thing I try to draw your I to pretty frequently where if we go to these round number strikes they're almost always more active than other strikes in terms of open interest and that's because of this very natural tendency so for example if I look at these 25 calls in 18 o there's 11,900 of them then if I go to the 30s round number there's 4 47,000 of them then if I go into the 20s round number again kind of moving in 5 Lots here there's 11,000 of them so even though there's options that are much better closer to the money like these they're still smaller size than something like the 20s or the 25s or the 30s human tendency you'll see this all the time in options markets so I would always say approach things with an open mind who knows what's happening but also understand the landscape and this kind of thing is very very normal
